gsd-smartcard sends TRANSMIT every second with YubiKey
gsd-smartcard sends TRANSMIT every second with YubiKey

note.body:
Got a f29. It appears to use the simulated call for both. The difference appears to be in secmod_HandleWaitForSlotEvent in nss. When it loops over all of the slots in fc29 it doesn't include a Yubico slot. However, in fc30 the Yubico slot is present.

Tested using: ```b pk11util.c:1162 if slot->slot_name[0] == 'Y'```

events.target_title: gsd-smartcard sends TRANSMIT every second with YubiKey

note.body: This behaviour is also present if I plug in a CAC card into the smartcard reader on both fedora 30 and fedora 29. Since this appears to be the default behaviour for a smartcard maybe the issue is to do with nss using `sc_pkcs15_get_pin_info` which uses `sc_lock` when it's just trying to do `nssSlot_IsTokenPresent`?

events.target_title: gsd-smartcard sends TRANSMIT every second with YubiKey

note.body:
Linked to:
https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/issues/1771

With the addition:
SoftHSM doesn't support C_WaitForSlotEvent. But also p11-kit doesn't support C_WaitForSlotEvent in blocking mode. We should probably change gsd-smartcard to use non-blocking mode.

```c++
#include <stdlib.h>
```

events.target_title: Copied filenames prefixed with `x-special/nautilus-clipboard copy file://`

note.body:
Hello everyone,

I was really fond of this feature, using it hundreds of times a day to copy file paths from Nautilus to GUAKE terminal, so I'm trying to find a workaround for myself that does not includes further key presses or changing my workflow too much. 

Following the direction of this [stackoverflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25900770/how-to-catch-the-clipboard-event-onchangeclipboard-equivalent-from-any-applica/25961646#25961646) 
I set up a daemon intercepting clipboard events and when appropriate extracting file path from the annoying mime string. 

```python
from gi.repository import Gtk, Gdk
import re

def callBack(*args):
    text = clip.wait_for_text()
    if re.findall('nautilus-clipboard', text):
        text = text.split('\n')[2].replace('file://','')
        clip.set_text(text, -1)

clip = Gtk.Clipboard.get(Gdk.SELECTION_CLIPBOARD)
clip.connect('owner-change', callBack)
Gtk.main()
```

..a bit dangerous, but it seems to work well for now.

Hope this can be of help

events.target_title: Window sometimes goes dark after waking from suspend

note.body:
I have a suspicion of what might be contributing. I also have `gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.wm.preferences visual-bell-type frame-flash` which darkens my terminal (including window decorations) when emitting a bell. When I take a screen cap of what the terminal looks like while being flashed, it looks pretty much the same as the dark window I initially attached. Maybe the flash is getting stuck somehow so it doesn't unflash back to normal? Maybe this could happen if the bell occurs during a suspend/wake due to a missed timer?

![Screencast_from_08-19-2019_03_11_44_PM](/uploads/ac2986854d90b33b863cafe78ae43ccb/Screencast_from_08-19-2019_03_11_44_PM.webm)

events.target_title: Window sometimes goes dark after waking from suspend

note.body:
So there is an issue with the bell getting stuck but I'm not sure it's the same issue. I'll describe it here since it's the only reproduction I have.

I just ran `while true; do echo -n ^G; done` and suspended/woke my computer. Interestingly, when I maximize the window there is a dark square the size of the unmaximized terminal window. Opening a new window opens a normal not darkened window. Continuing to emit bells has no visible effect when the window is unmaximized, but when maximized (so the darkened region does not cover the window) the rest of the window flashes.

Although the symptoms are similar, there are a few differences with the original report. When the bell is stuck the window appears black, while in the original report it is very dark. Also I'm quite sure in the original report that the entire window remains dark even when maximized.

![Screenshot_from_2019-08-20_10-16-07](/uploads/7af624d9553d2ddcdc40e25c8f0d1007/Screenshot_from_2019-08-20_10-16-07.png)

events.target_title: Mail filtering rules

note.body:
I'm not Rémy but I can give two examples :
- Moving on choosed folder (or labelling) from specific sender's adress 
- Moving on choosed folder (or labelling) from specific term on the object's mail

And I suppose that moving to the trash can be considered as a deletion and it's not a bad thing to reduce the options to keep it as simple as possible. I think that with this we cover a lot of use cases, the classification for a particular term in the body of the message seems rare to me.

I was thinking about this, how to add filters keeping UI simple and without a heavy interface, and tell me what do you think about this : at least a "move/label" button in the options of an opened mail and when you choose it for a single action, you could propose to automatize the action proposing sender (adress) or object criterias ?

events.target_title: Allowed to enter numbers with multiple decimal points

note.body:
I'm dissatisfied with this change, as it prevents me from using the calculator as I was used to and forces me to use an unintuitive workaround:

I frequently end up editing the result of a calculation into a new calculation in which the result is used, such as in subtraction. If I want to reuse the result as the subtrahend, my usual workflow is to press Home, type the minuend, then the minus sign and eventually Enter. This has been broken by the patch in cases when both the minuend and the subtrahend are decimals, because the calculator now ignores the decimal sign in the minuend if I try to type it (it considers the two a single number, because the minus sign that divides them is not yet present). The workaround is obviously to type the minus first, then again Home and then type the minuend, but that's counterintuitive.

I run into this problem frequently, such as when calculating with money. Look at the attached picture to see when the problem appears (I was about to subtract the last result from 2577,3 but got stuck on not being able to type the decimal sign): ![decimal-subtraction](/uploads/1dde4cf8473884b7ce2fea2294104823/decimal-subtraction.png)

What is even weirder – I can get a second decimal sign into the expression by clicking any of the expressions in the history pane (here no double decimal sign check occurs). Due to all this, I think the current patch is clearly suboptimal - creating more problems than it solves.

events.target_title: [RFE] Ask for firewall zone upon first connection
[RFE] Ask for network trustworthiness upon first connection
Add some simplified support for firewall profiles
Add some simplified support for firewall profiles

note.body:
> No, it was because it was mostly useless, eventually broke folks' setups, and the defaults would probably work just fine.

Half of the Fedora community (ok, I don't have the numbers, but given the flame that from time to time is unleashed in the mailing list, this estimation is probably fair) thinks that the defaults in Fedora Workstation are not fine. That's why I'm here proposing this. I've read also that many people are not fine either with having ufw disabled by default in Ubuntu (even in Ubuntu Server!).

> That's false. There was never any integration with ufw

I'm not claiming there was integration with ufw, I'm just saying that my proposal would be applicable to other firewalls apart from firewalld, that is sufficiently general to be interesting for many distros.

> firewalld still has a default configuration on Fedora Workstation. `/usr/lib/firewalld/zones/FedoraWorkstation.xml` contains:

I'm perfectly aware of that.

> The default configuration is already secure, eg. it doesn't leak the person's username, it has a greatly reduced number of system services available and allowed.

That's false. Every single port > 1024 is open. The firewall is enabled, but it's effectively mostly useless.

> I'd invite you to read this blog post, which has more information about why things are the way they are:

I read that post. I know why things are the way they are: because a closed firewall would break many applications such as sharing music in your home network.

But users may be sharing music in many public networks. Having a very simple system to say, hey, this network is home, or this network is public, it's a cue for the connection manager to set a proper firewall rule if available.

events.target_title: [RFE] Ask for network trustworthiness upon first connection

note.body:
> This behaviour would be the opposite of a good security question: https://lwn.net/Articles/562902/

The proposal is integrated in the network selector. Thus, the user is not "doing something else" and then it's interrupted. The user is connecting to a network, and this is part of the process (just one click).

> We mostly try to consider each new network we connect to to be a public network, and don't share anything on it by default.

That's fine, but that's a different thing. This is about selecting a proper firewall configuration, and this is something that GNOME is not doing, and cannot do. Because firewalls are complicated, and this is why they are basically disabled.

As things are, Fedora Workstation ships a permanently open firewall by default, and Ubuntu ships no firewall by default. So even if a user makes the wrong choice and selects "home network" in a public network, then they would have the very same situation that they have now: no firewalling. But the right choice would led to improved security.

So what I'm proposing is: one click, no other cons, improved security.

> So sharing things then becomes a conscious decision by the user to start sharing something, and user intent is a better security than asking whether a network is secure, without knowing the implications of that,

You are assuming that ports are binded and applications are accesible always under user intent, that the user knows the implications of opening or running every single application. I don't think that's reasonable.

> as the poor Windows UI for that case shows.

And you emit this judgement based on what exactly? Did you do some user tests? And even if it is, then maybe this is an opportunity to enhance it.

events.target_title: Add some simplified support for firewall profiles

note.body:
> This should already be locked down for any sharing managed by GNOME.

That's what I'm trying to say. The "sharing music" was a simple example. The thing is: not everything is controlled by GNOME, and even if there's some API they could use to decide, we cannot ensure it would be used. That's why firewalls were invented.

events.target_title: Add some simplified support for firewall profiles

note.body:
BTW, another way would be:

- GNOME considers each new network as public by default, and sharing is disabled.

Then, why wouldn't you also close the firewall by default and then open it as soon as the user toggles the "sharing" button? It's exactly the same you have now, but with an additional action: if there's a firewall enabled, choose an appropriate rule. Same user experience, but additional restrictions over apps that GNOME doesn't control.

events.target_title: Add some simplified support for firewall profiles

note.body: I'm disappointed that you are not willing even to discuss a thing. Even accepting that Windows has a bad interface for this, my last proposal was: if you are already opening/closing shares with a "sharing" button, why don't you do the same with the firewall with the same action?, which doesn't require any UI change.

Thai line break is broken after Unicode 11 changes
Thai line break is broken after Unicode 11 changes

note.body:
I think it might be better to revert the patch for now, as anything that linked against pango 1.44 cannot do Thai word breaking at all (and resulting in broken layout, etc. in Thai). Though, I'm not familiar with neither libthai nor pango enough to make a suggestion.

Also since Thai word breaking heavily relies on dictionary, I'm not sure if it's possible to standardizing Thai word breaking in Unicode at all. There are some efforts in [Southeast Asian layout task force](https://w3c.github.io/sealreq/thai/) in W3C about using ZWSP/WJ to indicate word boundaries, but it still assumes dictionary are used for preliminary word breaking. 

I think [thep](https://w3c.github.io/sealreq/thai/) (libthai's author) is the most qualified person on this topic.

note.body:
Seems reasonable to support these keys - actually most applications support these keys just fine. Support for them is so widespread that I was actually surprised that gimp didn't - at first I assumed it was the other application's fault for not copying compatible image data to the clipboard. 

Adding support for multiple key bindings to do the same thing might actually be easier / more generally appealing ?

Please make your program stop corrupting my pictures without cause.
Please make your program stop corrupting my pictures without cause.

note.body:
The version is Gimp 2:10:8. I downloaded off of GIMP's website. I am using
Windows 10. And I deleted the file as I found it pointless to keep around a
corrupted file.

I made it confidential because I'm not looking to get the file back. I'm
simply letting GIMP staff know that their program is randomly corrupting
xcf files so that they can fix it to where it doesn't do that.

What I meant by "The last picture I drew, all I did was tell GIMP not to
save my picture only to open it up later", I meant that I didn't want it to
save the changes I made to the image so I click the "discard changes"
button. The file was already saved to my external hard drive, I just didn't
want it to save the changes I made to the file. Sorry for not clarifying.

I don't recall the exact words the message said, but it was something along
the lines of "cannot open [file name]. This file has become corrupted and
cannot be opened." Probably not too helpful, but that's what I recall.

On a side note, I'm starting to suspect maybe the program is unstable when
using files on external hard drives. I may be totally wrong, but it might
give some lead way.

Anyways thanks for the response and sorry for the anger. Just frustrating
when you spend hours working on something only to have to start complete
over for seemingly no reason.

push_data.commit_title: Fix Null Pointer dereference for path.

events.target_title: gio: Fix Null Pointer Access for object path.
gio: Fix Null Pointer Access for object path.

note.body:
Yes functionally its same only. But the patch avoid 2 variable and checks NULL before first usage.
If an application is passing path using a parameter (like pointer) it could be possible it could miss NUll check.
To be at safer side, gio must check for NULL to avoid any crash in its implementation like in strrchr().

events.target_title: gio: Fix Null Pointer Access for object path.
gio: Fix Null Pointer Access for object path.

note.body:
Yes you are right validate_headers() should reject it before hand.
But then what is use of below check?
```
  object_path = g_dbus_message_get_path (message);
  g_assert (object_path != NULL);
```
And why to use 2 variables for same field.
Also if this NULL check is needed why we not doing it at first use.

note.body:
I'm still not able to reproduce the timeout with xmllint. I tried the options you suggested.

Do you mind clarifying how the bitmask works.

> 278362521

1 0000 1001 0111 0111 1001 1001 1001

and this translates to a different set of flags (--recover --dtdattr --valid ...) than the one you mentioned, right?

```c
typedef enum {
    XML_PARSE_RECOVER	= 1<<0,	/* recover on errors */
    XML_PARSE_NOENT	= 1<<1,	/* substitute entities */
    XML_PARSE_DTDLOAD	= 1<<2,	/* load the external subset */
    XML_PARSE_DTDATTR	= 1<<3,	/* default DTD attributes */
    XML_PARSE_DTDVALID	= 1<<4,	/* validate with the DTD */
    XML_PARSE_NOERROR	= 1<<5,	/* suppress error reports */
    XML_PARSE_NOWARNING	= 1<<6,	/* suppress warning reports */
    XML_PARSE_PEDANTIC	= 1<<7,	/* pedantic error reporting */
    XML_PARSE_NOBLANKS	= 1<<8,	/* remove blank nodes */
    XML_PARSE_SAX1	= 1<<9,	/* use the SAX1 interface internally */
    XML_PARSE_XINCLUDE	= 1<<10,/* Implement XInclude substitition  */
    XML_PARSE_NONET	= 1<<11,/* Forbid network access */
    XML_PARSE_NODICT	= 1<<12,/* Do not reuse the context dictionary */
    XML_PARSE_NSCLEAN	= 1<<13,/* remove redundant namespaces declarations */
    XML_PARSE_NOCDATA	= 1<<14,/* merge CDATA as text nodes */
    XML_PARSE_NOXINCNODE= 1<<15,/* do not generate XINCLUDE START/END nodes */
    XML_PARSE_COMPACT   = 1<<16,/* compact small text nodes; no modification of
                                   the tree allowed afterwards (will possibly
				   crash if you try to modify the tree) */
    XML_PARSE_OLD10	= 1<<17,/* parse using XML-1.0 before update 5 */
    XML_PARSE_NOBASEFIX = 1<<18,/* do not fixup XINCLUDE xml:base uris */
    XML_PARSE_HUGE      = 1<<19,/* relax any hardcoded limit from the parser */
    XML_PARSE_OLDSAX    = 1<<20,/* parse using SAX2 interface before 2.7.0 */
    XML_PARSE_IGNORE_ENC= 1<<21,/* ignore internal document encoding hint */
    XML_PARSE_BIG_LINES = 1<<22 /* Store big lines numbers in text PSVI field */
} xmlParserOption;
```

events.target_title: Brightness value set is lost if the screen is rotated with xrandr

note.body: Should we need to file this bug in mutter?

events.target_title: Brightness value set is lost if the screen is rotated with xrandr

note.body:
For brightness there are two mechanisms. `xrandr --props` shows a brightness and we could change it using

`xrandr --output HDMI-1 --brightness 0.2`

Otherwise we need to modify `/sys/class/backlight/*/brightness`. Modifying sysfs maybe done by `gsd-backlight-helper`.

The issue happens when we use `xrandr`.

Anyway I will look into those files. Thank you.

events.target_title: Artists and Albums appear mutliple times

note.body:
I am experiencing the same issue. Albums are appearing multiple times in the album list, and each copy of the album that appears contains only a single track except for one, which contains all the remaining tracks.

I've tried deleting the Lollypop database and starting from scratch, and I see a different numbers of these "duplicate" albums. It seems to happen to different albums each time I do this to.

I've checked that the tags are correct (they are Ogg opus files in case that's relevant). I'm using Lollypop 1.2.16 Flatpak on Debian Buster.

Edit: the above was testing on a subset of my library. I just tried importing my entire library and the issue seems to have resolved itself. Not sure what was going on there, but it's resolved now.

note.body: Updated to all latest packages, looked initially like it was still not working, but suddenly started to after about five minutes or so. I'll close the case, thanks for your help.

events.target_title: Unplugging a laptop should reset automatic suspend timeout
Support WebExtensions

note.body:
Hello, I see there is no news about this topic since 3 years. Therefore, it seems that there is no intention from developers to port WebExtensions to GNOME Web. 

But I have a question: is it **technically** possible to make a fork of GNOME Web and add WebExtensions to it? 

Thank you for your feedback.

events.target_title: Support WebExtensions

note.body:
Thank you very much for your quick answer. As you may know, Purism is desiging a smartphone (Librem 5) with GNOME Web as the main browser and many people are asking about Firefox (mainly due to the lack of WebExtensions in GNOME Web). So I am really happy that you consider to add it as a feature ! 

I am sure that with this feature, GNOME Web can be one of the best browser (Chromium is too much influenced by Google decisions, while Firefox could be almost perfect but has too many relationship with sponsoring and therefore incorporates code related to its business partners (Pocket, Google, the Mister Robot add-on episode, etc.) that you have to disable in `about:config` as well as choices that can bother some people like Firefox Sync which repatriates data, the Firefox health check-up which is `opt-in` by default, etc. 

This is acceptable to some, but for others it is a problem and they are looking for a web browser that allows them to browse the Internet and use add-ons and that's all, and GNOME Web has a great opportunity to make a difference on that.

events.target_title: Add option to show public folders beside user folders
Add option to show public folders beside user folders

note.body:
Thanks for looking into it :)

Regarding the performance my guess is, that Outlook does not download the whole structure as well. It starts with the top level and queries subtrees only when you expand them. 

From a users point of view, the current subscription menu works more or less the same as the Favourites in Outlook. Main difference is, that it is lacking the functionality to subscribe to whole subtrees including auto-refresh, when a folder gets added. Although this functionality would be huge improvement on itself, you would still have no way to actually create public folders.

My idea for a public folder browsing option would be more like a separate Exchange account, which does not show the contents of one account but the public folder hierarchy instead. This way it would be opt-in. Performance-wise it would depend on whether it would be possible to not grab the complete structure on first connect but only when you drill down further. In any case it should never cache elements, since this will surely get out of hand quickly.

events.target_title: Merge the DDS plug-in to GIMP and ship it by default

note.body:
About the "need" to merge and mantain the dds file format:

The DirectDraw Surface container file format (uses the filename extension DDS), is a Microsoft format for storing data compressed with the proprietary S3 Texture Compression (S3TC) algorithm,[1] which can be decompressed in hardware by GPUs. This makes the format useful for storing graphical textures and cubic environment maps as a data file, both compressed and uncompressed.[2] The file extension for this data format is '.dds'.
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirectDraw_Surface)

Basically a lot of games use dds format for their texutures. Today, more and more games become moddable - allow users to expand or replace the content of the games. Moddability can prove significant for some games. For example, Bethesda games of which most notably Skyrim. Have a quick  look at [nexusmods](https://www.nexusmods.com/) for example. A lot of these authors use gimp to make textures and they did so with the dds plugin. 

In my opinion, there is a point in developing this plugin. I am not sure, but you may be able to help yourselves in the implementation by studying some other open source projects which support dds file format. Actually, I also came here because of the dds format.

I hope you will find someone to mantain the dds support. You have my blessing.

events.target_title: Merge the DDS plug-in to GIMP and ship it by default

note.body: Yay!!! ;) Thank you!

events.target_title: Make path bar visible when clicking beside path buttons

note.body:
**More use cases:**

* User has used to see what they are copying (instead of right clicking the path object and selecting copy)
* User has location for files to edit (e.g. `~/.config/application`) and would like to open it
* User likes to open a path to a remote server location (e.g. `sftp://example.com/my/home`)

**More solitions:**

Do it the same way as Dolphin does it. Personally, they have the perfect solution for the UI design.

The path has always a 10px space for clicking with the mouse. When hovering over the space, there is visible bar (`|`), which is same as with any text field, and a tooltip "click to edit location".

When the edit bar is open, there is "ok, I'm ready" button and a clear button. Pressing the first, will change the edit bar back to the clickable object. Pressing the clear will clear the path and show different protocols as a dropdown. Always, the text field includes a dropdown with latest locations and so on.

events.target_title: Make GLib valgrind friendly

note.body: If you are really paranoid you could make the `g_mem_make_valgrind_happy` function not do anything if you don't set a special env variable. For another level of paranoia you could make it `g_mem_make_valgrind_happy(const char *tag)` and if the envar `G_MEMORY_VALGRIND_TAG=tag` doesn't match it will be ignored. So a application that it's call to g_mem_make_valgrind_happy be the last one.

note.body:
Hi @mjog 

Below is a copy from https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1746095

I cannot had you because I do not know your e-mail address (send me an e-mail to olibre@Lmap.org).
However, you can also ask access to Ego Cordatus, Thomas Moschny or Michel Alexandre Salim if you know them.

----------------------------------------------------

Description of problem:
This bug has been reported at :
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/issues/545


**Bug summary**

New mail window disappeared (crashed?) while Geary was unsuccessfully attempting to connect (my GMail credentials had expired, maybe due to 2FA activation).
But the mail content has not been saved within the Drafts folder. 

**Steps to reproduce**

 1. Enable 2FA on Gmail settings the previous day (G Suite)  
    => Gmail credential is marked has expired on GNOME settings
 2. Do not change anything on Geary or GNOME side  
    => I think Geary was unsuccessfully attempting to connect to my GMail account because my new inbox mails were not updated
 3. Create a new e-mail using a detached window and fill a long mail
 4. After about 30 minutes, format two lines using bullet points, and try to use [Ctrl] + [Enter] to split one bullet point into two lines
 5. Suddenly, the detached window disappeared, but Geary is still running.
 6. My long e-mail does not seems to be saved (e.g. not in the Drafts folder)

**What is the current bug behavior?**

* The detached window disappeared.
* Currently edited mail not in Drafts folder.

**What is the expected correct behavior?**

* No window should close (or crash) when not connecting to Gmail or when pressing [Ctrl] + [Enter]. 
* Any edited mail should be stored in local Drafts folder.

events.target_title: Support to unlock screen with U2F device only

note.body:
I know very little about PAM but my impression was that every service used a different file in /etc/pam.d.

So my preferred solution would be to use "gdm-password" for initial login and "gpm-unlock" for the other case. That way, I could add "auth sufficient pam_u2f.so cue" to the latter file.

The SO article mentioned https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/d9ad834eac86ee55340ee5a46322a6c27ea09094/js/gdm/util.js which ought to be the place where you can add more service names.

events.target_title: Revert "app: fix drawing of the empty canvas wilber"

note.body:
You may not care, but I want to share an email I got shortly after opening this issue.

> Apologies for the interruption, but I came across your recent open issue on Gitlab regarding the Wilber red eye flash 'easter-egg' and would just like to ask for a small piece of clarity -- first to make sure of the time it occurs, is it really 23 minutes and 23 seconds or 23 hours and 23 minutes? I set up a capture for the former but didn't see anything happen, but could it be that it needs to be focused for 23 minutes for the eyes to blink? Secondly, do you recall how fast the animation was. for the purpose of recording without dropping frames? Oh and lastly, which version of GIMP was your friend using, just to be sure? 

> I really appreciate your time taken to respond if possible, because I find this kind of secret really alarming personally as someone who easily suffers from panic attacks that arise from possible delusions and your find will definitely help some people who feel the same

Clearly, things like this hurt people.

events.target_title: VPN icon not showing up in status area

note.body:
On Gnome-Shell 3.30.2-9, I have the same problem.
I imported a VPN Connection from `.ovpn` file, filled in the username and password, and when turned on it immediately toggles off.

The (rather large and seemingly containing a lot of duplicates) unfiltered output of
`sudo journalctl /usr/bin/gnome-shell -f -o cat`

can be found here: https://pastebin.com/vRC9vcxC

---
When running  
`/usr/bin/gnome-shell --version` I get  
`GNOME Shell 3.30.2`,

but when I run  
`apt-cache show gnome-shell | grep Version` I get  
`Version: 3.30.2-9`  
`Version: 3.22.3-3`

Not sure if that makes a difference
